participants.participant: Dr. Josef Ackermann, Chairman of the Management Board and the Group Executive Committee
Anthony di Iorio, Chief Financial Officer

plist.p: Welcome everybody in Frankfurt in our new inter-remestic headquarter to our Analyst Meeting on the occasion the Fourth Quarter Results, which we released this morning.
With me is the top management of the house. We have Joe Ackermann, we have to your left Tony Di Iorio, Chief Financial Officer and we have to your right Hugo Bnziger, our Chief Risk Officer.

We would like to proceed as following. Two presentations, Joe first and then Tony, on the results and on our strategic positioning. And then, we enter as usual into discussion with you all here in Frankfurt. We appreciate you came, joining us for this meeting. And after that we prepare to take questions from all the participants of the international conference call which is linked with this event. Also we are stream – streaming, we are broadcasting this event through our website.

With that one more remark, Joe, before I ask you to take the panel and speak from over there, is in interest of time, I want to save you the trouble that I read out all our legal disclaimers, which normally would have to. So for good order, I assume you have all read it, understood it, and we can take them to the minutes, so to speak.
With that Joe, I would like to ask you to give your presentation.
Thank you. Good afternoon, ladies and gentlemen. First, let me say a few words about the bank in 2007 and then of course say a few words about 2008.

I think that you probably know, in the meantime, revenues have been up 8% to €30.7 billion, profit is up bottom line by 7% is 2.5 and pre-tax 8.7. I would like to make one comment as I read a little bit your interim comments in the meantime.

We had one provision. Third party conduit, nothing to do with the traditional business one-off is not a worsening or weakening of your credit environment, not at all. So it has nothing to do with that. It is really a one-off.

Still a little bit challenging to see whether it will be finally covered by the agreements we had. Let's see, but it is one-off event which we had to take because we couldn't fully document the way the agreement was looked out and that is a – is now they tested in our case and I'm very happy about that.

Then of course we had some tax events, Tony will talk about that briefly, which were in addition to the normal tax rate and we had a write down on impairment on intangibles and as I mentioned in two small businesses, but we took it now and so that had somewhat negative impact on our results. The operating strengths actually has been quite good.

What is really important, is the CIB businesses, now admittingly of course more coming from the first half and from the second, but for the full year we are only down 15% in CIB and about 22% in CB&S. So actually a relatively small and – I mean, compared to the record level of 2006, if you compare with 2005. Things look of course even better. But I think its important to say that we have the tested mark down to 2.2 billion and we still are only 15% below the record level of 2006, I think that is something, which, by the way, is also a good argument for our vision statement later on.

PCAM steady growth, of course, we have integration cost on the retail side. And we had this impairment in asset management, otherwise a strong good business in line with what we are expecting and I may come back to that quickly and we talked about '08.

Clearly, one of the out performances in the industry is our CB&S revenues. And we delivered on our pre-tax target, which 26% reported 29. But you know, we've this target definition, which is more narrow and more the underlying side of our business, 26% and the same EPS 13 reported and 10.79 underlying our target definition. That's why, we are proposing to the AGM to increase dividend to 450, a bit in line with our commitment, remember that, to increase our payout ratio over time.

The next one, the management agenda is unchanged, we stick to that. We are continuing our discipline. Having said that, I was asked several times on the first conference, have you taken lessons? Have you learned your lessons? Yes, of course, I mean, if I'm asked about the fraud event in Deutsche Bank, I'm not naïve and say this will never happen. We are confident that it doesn't happen. But immediately, we asked our auditors internal and external to look into that. I think that would be bad management not to do that. But this is not in any way a bad feeling, but I wouldn't like to say we're complacent, everything is perfect and then in three years from now, we do have a similar case. So we're looking that and starting that very carefully.

But as I said, we are confident. The same is true for our risk management. There are lessons to be learned. I think we did a better job then most of our peers, but are we perfect? No. I think we will look more into stress testing of our hedging strategies. We look more into notional amounts, our trading capital equivalent, we will give more to price signals to our traders, so they are not benefiting from a double A1 bank. They get the price signals, which they should get when they take high risk, and things like that. So there are things to be learned, improved and we are doing that very methodically.

We will continue to invest in organic growth in bolt on acquisitions. I think what is really a success story is our value creation in Asia. Especially in China, if you think you now have a 30% stake in the largest – third largest asset manager with quite a substantial invest in assets and we bought that in a very early stage, increased it now. And nowadays, I think we have quite some value created in it, so we've got it very reasonable. Same of course is true for our last year, where we have a nice stake and a good corporation agreement and more to come along these lines.

We will further grow our stable businesses, PCAM and GTB; and of course in investment banking, we are now benefiting – I don't want to offend anyone at this table, but some are more effective than others, and I think those who are less effective have good reason to push and to gain market share and that's exactly what we are doing.

So, next page, cost/income ratio is stable. The compensation ratio was 43%, so below last year. And what is also very important, we are not mortgaging the future – or we are mortgaging the future less than in previous years. So, what we have here now restricted equity units is below what we had last year. If you believe some rumors, some banks are mortgaging more.

The other thing is this famous liability side. We have not made anything – actually, for the full year, I think we have 19 million. Others have billions or more like billion. We are not doing that. First of all, we don't need; and secondly, I think it's wrong, because you are mortgaging the future and it's also not very logical. There's no economic value in it and your spreads widen because you have weaker credit. So in the theory, you can buy back your debt cheaper and that's what makes you more profitable. That's not the way we are doing it. So we have not mortgaged the future on that side, which is a very important argument, and we have not mortgaged the future in terms of compensation more than when we normally had for retention purposes, another good argument.

Problem loan ratio is down. Tier 1 ratio flat, 8.6, and at year-end still unrealized gains on our industrial holdings, but these are industrial holdings we have not taken into account yet other stakes, as I said, in Chinese banks, so this is the target industrial holdings.

Next one, we will have a positive impact from Basel II, so we are starting now at 9.4% since 1st of January. We have similar targets so that I don't have to go through that, as you see on the right hand side. The next – because I think we are showing more resilience and probably more stable, we are clearly funding cost advantages, which I tried to put. Although I have to say that CBS spreads are not fully reflecting the cost of funding. Actually, we always had good funding and even in times where other banks had difficulties in getting term money, we've got quite attractive term money because we were one of the banks big investors trusted. What we cannot offer is capital injections. Many would like to do a similar deal with us, we just don't need them.

Next one, we have organic growth. We have continued to grow our risk weighted assets, but as you see, return on risk weighted assets has been relatively stable, a little bit lower than in 2006. I should also mention that when we talk about return on equity, that we have a completely different capital base. We have about 4 billion more than we had in previous years. So we are not buying back shares or reducing capital in order to maximize return on equity. We are growing and we have added 4 billion in capital, and you will see that later on in more detail.

The next one, that's more of a reminder, we continue to grow our business in all areas. But we are not a friend of market cap maximization. I don't think that's a good strategy. We – important for us is not – neither the total assets, nor a number of branches, nor market cap. Important for us is the strategic positioning in our core businesses. And secondly, the return we achieve on our capital. That's all which counts. And it will be easy to buy a retail bank somewhere and to add another 20 or 30 billion, but I don't think that's strategically intelligent nor is it in interest of shareholder. So this dream of growth I do not share, or we do not share.

Then stable businesses. Over 3 billion now in GTB we are roughly 950, which is close to the billion target. On the retail, it is 1149, if you add the integration costs and the noris [norisbank] adjustment cost, it will be over 12, so 13 is not such a stretch. And in asset and wealth management they have a very, very good asset inflow and are making good progress, but we have taken this impairment charge in the fourth quarter.
On the next page, you'll see the money – net new money inflows, 59 billion, 40 billion in asset and wealth management, 19 billion in PBC which I think is very strong development.
Next one in CB&S, to fuel investment banking, we have net revenues which are flat to last year on record level. So I think that's another very important message.

And I would like to say a few words why we did somewhat better. First of all, I'm strong believer in management stability, I'm not a friend of if someone makes a mistake, he has to go and then you hire a new one at a higher price and he makes the same mistake two years later.

If you want to have experienced people, you have to tolerate that they can make mistakes in challenging terms, not twice but once; and so for us never a question of getting rid of people, who have done a fantastic job for very long. If someone underperforms then of course he will be replaced, if someone does something legally incorrect he has to go, but not in a market which is so challenging if he had some bad luck; so, very important that we have the same team in place as at the press conference for many, many years.

Secondly, a very tight risk and capital management; I think one of the reasons we were successful that in July when the first signal started we said, out, exit, whereas some others hoped for better times. And I feel here that if you are jeopardizing our bonus pool by doing this or you know when traders, investors come back from their vacation, they start buying again. We did not share that view; based on a more macro economic analysis, we felt that the subprime will not recover and that it will get worse and so we got out of related products and I think that's the major difference between those who did better than the others. And we are well diversified, very strong position on emerging economies which helped us tremendously, and as I said always access to funding sources at attractive rates compared to some of our peers.

Going forward you know that, that mega trends, in my view, are unchanged. Those who say, that originated as a thing of the past. They really don't know what they're talking about, if we change that model we'd have a recession on a global scale because we couldn't fund emerging economies anymore, we couldn't fund large cap companies anymore, it's just naïve to assume that. Will it change a little bit? Yes, certain things will be different, maybe more transparencies, but overall our position is that EBIT will continue and we are one of the best positioned in that.

Globalization will continue, we have added over 9,000 people last year, 40% of that in Asia. We have now 6,000 people in India alone. And global asset growth, strong outsourcing in the insurance business, insurance industry, through asset management, we're benefiting from that. And alternative investment is becoming more important, real estate, we believe, is one of the premier players in that market.

Now for the mission, first of all, I mean, we have hundreds of skeptics around us, too, and if I may say something on my birthday, I wouldn't dare to say that. Some of you I think are also now in environment where it is very messy. I mean if I had all these positions and billions of write-downs, I would probably be shocked too. So trying to differentiate between those who have such better positions than others, and I think that's an important first message.

Secondly, if we now give internally and I'm not saying we should naively be optimistic, that's not my point, but if you say everything will be bad and just lean back and wait, that is not what we should to do as managers. You have to take the risk and you have to say, we are going to achieve that and to make it credible as long as it is realistic. If it's not realistic, you'll be foolish, but I am very convinced that assuming that the real economy is not collapsing and when I say not collapsing, substantial slowdown in U.S., but no recession; relatively strong economy in Europe, Germany about 1.5%, not collapsing either but slowing down. And in the emerging economies still strong growth. If this is right, I don't think that the credit environment will change dramatically.

Secondly, we are assuming that there is not big a monoline tsunami hitting us and with dramatic dislocations of the market. So, I mean if this happens or other things then of course I – we'll come back and say, this is not based on our assumptions, but assuming that we have these positions which we have that markets will be more challenging in certain parts on the other hand flow business is very strong and January in sales trading was a good month because of that.

Now clearly, we've one big issue, that's the leveraged loan. If markets do not recover, prices have to be adjusted. If we can't place them we have to take them on our balance sheet, but the NIM is very important. So, maybe in the first few months, you will see it will be more on the negative side; then in the next nine months you will see them on the positive side.

So overall, we think from today's perspective that NIM is exceeding any markdowns and I think that is what I have in mind when we talk about 2008. I am not talking about February or March or April 2008. We are talking about the full year. And we have taken management actions. We are not expanding. We are not building up the way we would have liked to without the financial crises, so we are waiting and then we will see. So, costs are under control.

And overall, looking into our positions, we are confident that some businesses will outperform our ambitions; some will maybe a bit under-perform, but on average the 8.4 is still realistic. And as I said the Executive Committee is committed to that and we do everything to achieve that, what I've said this morning. If you are a Formula One driver and you start your race with saying I will be last any how, you better don't go there.

So if we said we are not going to make it then it will be a little bit weak. All we are saying – we take the courage as we did with the retail bank with the 25%. Many of you still have some of its report. It said how ridiculous and how naive and you will never achieve that. We achieved it. Even in the most turbulent year, we had 26% and retail was 1.150, so much higher than the 1 billion.

And I am very confident that we do the same and you have the management commitment and strength to do whatever is necessary to achieve that, but are we profitable? I cannot say how this year develops, I think people are a bit too negative now

Based on now we have now a book value per share of about 77, 78. If someone is saying the target price is 68, he is saying it should be value it at price-to-book of 0.9, everybody's guess, I would challenge that. I am just saying here you have different and I think its very important that you have a few people in the industry who have the courage to say things will turn out differently. Otherwise we can just start crying here and see the whole banking world collapses and this is not the case. Capital markets are strong. Liquidity is strong. There are lot of strategic buyers around and a tremendous strength in the emerging economies. So that is in a nutshell what I wanted to say but I am happy to be challenged by all of you. Thank you
Thanks, Joe. We hand over to Anthony

I'll go through this briefly without trying to repeat much of what Joe said but the first chart with pre-tax profits for the year 8.7; for the quarter 1.4, which is comparable to the third quarter. We'll talk about this more later but the difference between the two quarters, the third quarter had substantial write-downs, but it also benefited from substantial Corporate Investment gains.

In the fourth quarter, we had some Corporate Investment gains, but they were much more modest and as a result the quality earnings. Joe talked about the mark-to-market of the debt. We'll talk about that in more detail.

Next page, net income of a billion and we've shaded the fourth quarter last year and the third quarter this year to give you a sense of the special tax effects that were in each quarter. In the third quarter, this year we earned 1.6 billion and as we discussed when we presented those earnings, there were some substantial tax credits. One had to do with the revision of the German taxes, the impact that had on our deferred tax liabilities and others had to do with the settlement of some tax audits and similar and that was 600 million.

So in the third quarter we would have earned 1 billion, and we earned 1 billion after-tax this quarter. If you look at the fourth quarter last year we had about a 400 million credit, which was from the German tax law that changed the application of the dividend credits that were grandfathered.

So, as far as net income is concerned, it is about the same as the third quarter. The third quarter had substantial tax free gains in it as well I should mention and slightly below the fourth quarter last year, which was a record fourth quarter, very strong fourth quarter. So given the turbulent times we are in, given the difficulties that we have had to face it was a fairly steady tax rate for the quarter, was just under 33% and that fits within our guidance rate of 33 to 35 and we'll continue with that guidance.

Net revenues were up 2% against a very strong fourth quarter for the year, up 8%, which is remarkable when you consider the effects particularly of the summer months. I should add that we had no significant net write-downs in the quarter in our CDO or RMBS exposures. I'll touch later on the leverage finance book, there's a chart in the handouts that will show you what happened there and Corporate Investments contributed 165 to the quarter, which was the same about as contribution in the fourth quarter of last year. Go to the next page we look at expenses.

Our total expenses for the quarter were up from the third quarter but up slightly from the fourth quarter last year and I'd just like to comment on two elements. When we presented the third quarter numbers, many of you were skeptical as to whether we had taken down our bonus accrual too much.

If you remember, we came in at a comp ratio which was in the low 30s and at the time we said two things. We first told you how we do our bonus accrual, which is a year-to-date and then a true up over what had been accrued in the prior periods and because of the very strong first half, we released accruals in the third quarter that were made in the second and the first, in the first half of the year.
We indicated at that time that our targeted comp ratio for the year was going to be consistent with we were in the first half. And we are happy to report, you will see on the next page, that it is.

As far as the non-comp let me go back one page there, let's touch on that, as far as the non-comp, we came in at 2.1 comparable basis and again we spilt this to show a 200 million charge which I will explain. The 200 million consists of two elements, the 74 million which we took in the Asset Management, which was a write-off of the Scudder intangibles, and I will touch on that shortly in a little more detail. And then, because of the anomalies of insurance accounting, following the acquisition of Abbey, which was in the third quarter – fourth quarter of this year, we have to gross up investment gains on the insurance assets against the liabilities for two policyholders and the latter comes through as an expense. And so, although we take out a spread from those two, unfortunately we cannot report them on a net basis.

The net is still positive and we believe that the business on preliminary indications will produce the P&L forecast each year that was anticipated when it was approved – before it was approved when it was reviewed. So, those two elements we are going to begin showing or the second one in the Abbey, we're going to begin showing that separately just so that you can focus on where the expenses were.

When we presented the third quarter numbers, we also told you that in those numbers were some credits. There was an – recoveries on insurance claims that we had previously expensed and paid from the insurers because that does take some time to run through the claims process. In addition to that, we had a 138 million of VAT recoveries, which also have to be shown as an expense offset rather than revenue. And what we said is if you adjusted out for those two elements, then our run-rate in the third quarter of non-comp would have been about 2.1 billion.

If you look at this year – this quarter, there is an insurance recovery and there is a settlement. The insurance recovery is about the same as it was in the prior period, so that had a neutral effect. And the settlement on a claim we had was substantially lower than the 138 million. So, if you factor all of that in and the reason we put the headline here that G&A expenses are consistent with the effective run-rate of the second and third quarter, is that we avoided what happened here in prior years with the fourth quarter book.

We had fourth quarter expenses because at year-end there are special expenses that you can't charge off earlier in the year having to do with mailings, having to do with a number of other things, and – but we were about at the same run rate adjusted for those non-recurring items.

Now, if you go to the next page you'll see the ratios, the 76% cost/income ratio is impacted, that number would have been probably rounded to 75, without the Abbey adjustment and there were some other – there were some expenses in the quarter. I want to focus for a second on the comp ratio which is 44% for the quarter and 43% for the year. It came in where we said it would and as Joe said, we reduced in absolute terms the number of equity grants that we had as part of that process. The number is down from last year. On a relative basis, we followed about the same split as a percentage between cash and stock. So, we didn't change that. So, we have not mortgaged the future, what you will see is in the first quarter, a first quarter phenomenon which we explained last year because of the accelerated investing for people eligible for early retirement. So you'll see a pick up. But what we are doing is accelerating closer to the year in which the grant is made; the expense which we think is a good thing because it gives you a better sense of what's happening against costs.

The next slide has to do with the stable businesses. Joe discussed this; I just want to highlight one thing, in the fourth quarter, the 643 million is net of the 74 million. If we adjust for that, then the fourth quarter of the stable businesses is comparable to the first quarter of 2006, which was the best quarter. So, we're producing there and doing well.

Moving into the segment CB&S – is down 57% from the fourth quarter last year, but it's a very different quarter, up substantially from the third quarter because as I said earlier, we avoided the write-downs; we were able to, because of risk management practices and the early liquidation, we were able to avoid costs and we did have recovery.

If we looked at the businesses, the product lines where we had the 1.6 billion of trading losses in the third quarter and looked at the contribution of those businesses in the fourth, the number is positive. So, we had a shift from a 1.6 billion loss to a positive. And so, that shows the recovery of those businesses. Did we have write-downs in the CDO book? Did we have write-downs in other assets? Yes. Did we have hedges that offset them and was there a prudent risk management? Did our net exposures remain where we wanted them to? The answer to that is yes as well, and these results demonstrate real strength in the flow products. We'll go into them in debt and equities in a second and we had a record quarter on Advisory.

I just want to go back to something Joe said with regard to the mark-to-market of own debt. During the quarter, we booked a loss of 3 million. So in marking our debt to market, we took a loss of 3 million. We had 22 million in the third quarter and that brings us 19 million for the year.

As Joe said, it's very difficult to understand how you can ever economically realize this benefit. So what does this mean for you and for our investors? It means we're not mortgaging the future. Either we're sitting – have to be sitting on substantial excess liquidity to be able go out into the markets and buy your publicly traded debt, which very few banks are currently.

If you had to refinance that debt, you would have to refinance it at higher interest rates, and so you're going unwind the benefit through higher interest costs in the future. If it is a privately placed debt, the holder of that debt is not going to except a redemption, unless you've got a call feature of some type, and most of these structured notes that we apply to is not going to accept a discount on the face value. He is going to wait for maturity. So what you have to do for those, is accrete this benefit back through P&L as an expense to raise a liability to maturity date as to what it is.

So we're not criticizing anybody for doing anything. But we only want to point out the significance – because I think that was lost on a lot of analysts – the significance of what those gains mean. And we're assuming everybody accounted for them properly. Although the past week has just published a proposed change in rules that says that the debt has to be marked to the spread that represents the driver of that liability cost in the market.

So if it's privately placed notes, such as the ones we are valuing and the spread is widened two points or whatever, that's what you have to use, not the CDS, not the publicly traded debt spread. But – and that's the change they've proposed. Significance here is what does it mean for you and our shareholders, and we think it's not mortgaging the future.

If you look at debt, Sales & Trading, a sharp recovery from the third quarter, although down from the prior year quarter. The flow businesses effects in traditional fixed income, which we call rates, benefited from the quarter. Strong performance, a scalable platform and their great economies, the depth of our platform, the geographic reach are all beneficial with rates. As you can see, it's a flow business is in the structured products. On credit, we had no net write-downs in sub-prime and CDO and we continue reducing the size of the trade book.

As far as equities is concerned, the same story. A growth though from the third quarter – fourth quarter of last year. And the fourth quarter of last year had much larger designated prop trading profits than the fourth quarter this year. So both in terms of relative terms as well as absolute terms, the prop trading is down. Equity derivatives had strong performance, particularly in the retail products.

Our prime services business is growing well. We've just announced the acquisition of a hedge fund administration company in the United States and we think that that will complement that business. It's in GTB not in the CB&S, but nevertheless, it's another foray into a very important product area for us. Cash equities was up, and as the arrow shows, designated prop was down significantly.

Origination and Advisory, a record quarter for us on Advisory. You'll see the numbers in detail in the product breakdown. But we had 314 million of Advisory revenues in the quarter. Equity origination is also – was down but performed well. And on the leverage finance pipeline, we'll continue that on the next page. So you'll see what we did if you could.

Okay. This is an update of the chart that we showed at the end of the third quarter. And so what happened to our positions during the quarter. They dropped from 41.4 to 36.2. And you can see, where that 5 billion plus came from. Some of it was helped by FX but the significant is the sales of 5 billion. The 5 billion, if you go down to the development of the write-downs was sold for 80 million higher than the carrying value at the end of the third quarter.

So we sold them for a profit but that also indicated something about, for those positions at least, how close our marks were to market and demand. We took another 124 million of charges during the quarter. We reported in the press release that the net write-down was less than 50 and that's the 44 you can see on the chart. That's the combination of the 124 and the 80.

Our funded loans, at the end of the quarter were at 15 billion and the unfunded was at 20. And you can see the run-off of the commitment period down below, whether all those close or not is subject to conjecture and our guys are working very closely and very carefully to see where that goes.

The other importance is as far as how this is classified and how it's treated through P&L. We did not move any loans into the banking book, except those that at the time of the commitment, the intent was to hold.

So as we explained last period, every time a commitment is proposed, it has to be designated as to how much of that is the final hold. And that's an important thing that Hugo looks at, as far as risk management. So we didn't move anything. So that says that the book is still susceptible to market fluctuations and you can see we get almost 35 billion. How did we value these? The same way we valued them in prior periods, the same way we value trading positions.

The business – the CRM in this case, credit risk management go through the first review of the marks. They do it with market conditions as of December 31st, which is what is required. We then – our guys, finance guys go in to do the typical independent price review that they do on trading positions. And then on top of that our external auditors did a review of both, the pricing methods, the approach, as well as the values.

So that's where that is. GTB, if we can turn, had a record year. The quarter was up from the fourth quarter last year, best fourth quarter ever. We had very strong performance from trade finance as well as our cash management business. We announced, as I mentioned earlier during the quarter, the acquisition of a hedge fund administrator on the West Coast in America. And also in the year, we purchased the domestic custody business in Turkey of Garanti Bank. So those have not had any impact or significant impact yet on the results, but we expect that over the years, those will help us build the business further and particularly outside of Germany in emerging markets, which is where there is a big push on in this business.

Asset and Wealth Management, the fourth quarter was affected on a comparative basis by some specific items. The first, in the fourth quarter last year, we had significant gains from the sale of assets that were booked and we disclosed this. We didn't have those this quarter, and we indicated that these are lumpy. They don't come on a regular basis but they come when the sales or the performance fees are generated. In addition to that we took the 74 million charge. When we acquired Scudder, the purchase price was allocated to tangible assets, intangible assets and goodwill. Among the intangible assets was the value of investment management contracts. Two of the businesses that had intangibles on their investment; management contracts, the review we did this year indicated that the intangible value was impaired. One of them we wrote-off 100% because the numbers, the valuation allowed us to do that. And the second one, there is still a small piece left. And we'll have to see how the business develops. It's maybe 20% of this total that we have here, so there maybe another, in the future; hopefully, there won't be, and we'll see how businesses develop.

On PBC, we're up 13%. Again, it's the best fourth quarter we've had. The revenue – we had lower revenues from brokerage. There was a slowdown of activity. The fourth quarter is normally a slow quarter. And this is an individual business and we've had a slowdown in brokerage revenues from the third quarter. We had substantial net new moneys. We incurred cost for the relaunch of norisbank. We picked up about 2 billion of new deposits our deposits have gone from 1 billion to 3 billion in norisbank through that relaunch, and we'll continue that. And what they are going to focus on this year is growth, after substantial integration cost, we should see most of that go away, probably half way through the first quarter and that was significant. And we should see the fruits of the marketing and relaunch campaign both on loans as well as on deposits.

Turning to next page, as far as net new money; 59 billion for the year, 13 billion for the fourth quarter. It's important to look at the breakdown as well. PWM, which suffered from the costs of substantial build up in 2006, which we have described to you. We hired more than 400 people in that business, most of them or many of them in frontline or directly supporting the frontline. And we saw the benefits of that hiring both in the U.S., our former Alex. Brown, this is still not totally profitable, it's approaching break-even, but has improved substantially. But we've seen significant growth in Asia and good money flows from Asia as well.

Asset Management was the same phenomenon and if you look there, the amount of assets that we had coming in on institutional, retail as well as alternatives was very strong, and this should help in the future. But so far the hedges have produced more than enough money to write down our positions as it was needed. That was true in the fourth quarter and that has been true in the first month of January too. So I look at that relatively positively.
Great.

As far as Level 3, we will be disclosing, we're still finalizing the numbers, where we are is the assets will probably end up being in the high double-digits, liabilities in the low double-digits. It's something, again, you've got to look at very carefully because it's a mix of cash at the notional amount, a derivative at the mark-to-market amount. What is observable and what isn't is also an open question. The growth from the end of 2006 was principally in two areas, in the leverage finance loans we've booked and you can see on the page we've included how much those were, whether we carry them on trading or in the banking book. When we talk about Risk Weighted Asset growth in the investment bank, you shouldn't forget that our business strategy is to win more clients, to do more derivative business, so one thing that has increased when you look at the breakdown, our exposures to counterparties that the economies, the global transaction bank has increased, so that contributes.

Another thing is, if you add more derivative clients then the replacement value of your derivatives goes up by the number. And thirdly, these markets are very volatile.
